segments.text: The machine sitting in the beautiful, looks like a two-story living room with Dr. Wayne Hall on June 10.
And let's see, say something on your mic and let's see if it works.
Yeah, it's June 10th and lovely June day outside.
The purpose of these interviews is to try to record
for posterity and anybody else that wants to learn more about how A&M truly came to be what it is today.
And I remember in the early 60s, your key, key role
Let's go back before A&M.
Would you please, so that any scholar might want to know about your background, describe your background before you came to A&M.
Okay, Haskell.
I saw light of day in Montana on the boondocks of northwestern Montana on a cattle wheat ranch where my dad had homesteaded in the early days.
But my mother got tired of the wilds and wanted the kids to have better education that was available in our surroundings in Montana.
So she insisted we go back to Iowa, which was the native state of both originally.
And we did.
I grew up on a western Iowa farm.
a poor country kid in a family of thirteen children.
And all of us went through high school and many through college.
I guess we learned our lessons in the dirt of the Iowa hills.
From there I went to the University of Iowa.
When I finished, my wife and I became married for a short while together because World War II was beckoning and I enlisted in the Navy six months after I received my degree.
I served in the Navy in all the theaters of action.

And although unknown at the time, the landings at the Omaha beachhead where old Rudder led it with his rangers, my destroyer squadron escorted them to the beachhead and gave them the fire support from the seaward side during the landings.
Oh.
What was your destroyer's name?
It was the USS Frankfurt, the 497.
At that time, we were part of the Destroyer Squadron 18, which gave a lot of the fire support for the landings, not only at Omaha, but at Utah Beach and the others there.

After the war, I went back to Iowa City, where my wife was living at the time, and where we had gone to school at the university, and mulling over what to do, whether to go back into education or find a job or what.
I was talking with the former head of my department, and he said, Well, why don't you come back and go to graduate school?
He said, the GI Bill will pay your way, and I was partly disabled, doing a disabled veteran thing and got special things.
Essentially got my way paid through graduate school.
Received my Ph.D. in two years there.
Majored in?
I majored in biochemistry and physiology.
My thesis was written in plant physiology because my major professor was a plant physiologist.
I took the best job I thought was available at the time, which was University of Kentucky as assistant professor of botany.
While there, after two months, the department chairman came in, whose name was Dr. Herbert Riley.
He said, Hall, I'm going to Oak Ridge.
I've got a scholarship.
I want to make you the acting department chair.
I said, what?
I was the only assistant professor in the thing, the new kid on the block, and here were the others who were full professors and so forth.
But then I found out shortly the reason, because none of them would talk to each other, and I was the only one he could get to take the job.
Well, anyway, we ended up and I got with all the workload of being chairman and starting a new career as a teacher, researcher.
I had to give up research when I took over the chairmanship.
I got a call from Texas A&M, one of my former graduate school colleagues had taken a job at A&M.
Now what year was that call?
That was in 1948.
His name was Dr. Wayne McElrath.
He wanted to know if I was interested in coming to Texas A&M.
They had an assistant professorship available in their department, which had been
following the reorganization of 1948.
I don't know if you recall, the whole A&M system was reorganized at that time.
In fact, it was brought in, the first chancellor was appointed, Gib Gilchrist.
And I got to talking with Wayne, both names, of course, were Wayne.
I called him Mac and said, Mac, sounds interesting.
I said, have the department chairman call me and we'll talk.
So he did, whose name was Dr. Albert Dunlap at that time.
He called, and he finally, after about three months, convinced me to come to A&M.
Kept raising the salary, which was great in those days, because salaries were very low.
What was your beginning salary?
The beginning salary here was $5,200, whereas the Kentucky was $4,400.
And this was for 12 months.
No, originally it was for nine months, but the promise I'd be made in a 12-month appointment through the Texas Agriculture Experiment Station.
I was in the College of Agriculture.
And Dr. Lewis, or D. Lewis, did promise me a 25% appointment in the Experiment Station, which came the following year.
And, well, that's how I came to A&M.
All right.
So you arrived in the fall of 40?
It was the summer, actually.
Summer of 49.
Describe the campus as you first saw it.
Well, I won't paint it quite as bleak as I did in this little treatise I did on A&M.
But it was after being used to the lush green grass of Kentucky, the blue grass area.
Literally, it is a beautiful area.
Oh, it's beautiful.
When we came in, it was in August, the middle of August.
In those days, they didn't water the campus, and they'd been in a prolonged drought for some three years, and the dust was blowing.
It was sort of a disheartening experience.
In fact, I can remember Dorothy saying, kids got out, we arrived on the campus, didn't know where to go, so we parked what looked like sort of a garage area.
And the dust was blowing.
And Dorothy said, my gosh, I hope we wished we had not left Kentucky.
And the kids were hungry and wanted to find something to eat.
And I was trying to find the place where I was to go.
And I hailed what turned out to be an Aggie student in his uniform, even though it was summertime, but he was still in uniform.
And I said, can you tell me where the Department of Plant Physiology and Pathology is located?
He said, sure.
He said, it's right next to the building where I work.
So he escorted me across, and I met Dr. Dunlap, and that's where I started.
And where did you all live when you first
Dr. Dunlap agreed when he hired me that he would find a home for us, a house to rent.
We had agreed the price we were willing to pay, which was small in those days, and it was over in Bryan.
The former, the mayor of Bryan at that time owned the house.
And Dr. Dunlap knew him.
He was a former Aggie.
And, well, one of the lakes up near Hearn is named after him now, Dansby.
Oh.
Roland Dansby.
Roland, uh-huh, sure.
And he was in a number of businesses.
He had an insurance business.
He had a ranch farm.
Oh, I don't know, he had half a dozen things in the fire at the time.
He was very active, and he was a real southern gentleman.
And we lived there, and of course commuting back and forth and having only one old beat-up Ford, it became a real problem for Dorothy to get out to get anything.
So finally I said, why don't we look and see if we can get closer to the campus?
Maybe we can get close enough I can walk to work, and you can have the car then and do whatever you want to do.
We found a little new apartment being built on Second Street across from the Presbyterian Church there.
At Northgate.
At Northgate, yeah.
It was brand new.
It was very small, but it was new, and it was without air conditioning.
Nothing was air conditioned in those days, so we got a water cooler, which only partly worked, and eventually got a window air conditioner.
So I could walk.
I actually walked from Northgate to the campus each morning, or most mornings anyway.
You were in the Department of Plant?
Plant Physiology and Pathology, which had been formed in 1948.
How many were in that department then, do you remember?
Oh, I think there was ten professors, ranging all the way from assistant professor to full professor.
And the dean in those days?
The dean in those days was Dr. Shepardson, who was a dairy scientist in agriculture.
And in 1950, I believe it was, no, no, no, 1954,
He was offered a position on the Federal Reserve Bank in Washington, which he took, which was a real plum in those days, to be invited from little podunk college to Washington.
And he left, and Jimmy Adams, who was the formerly head of agronomy and soil science, became dean.
And it progressed from there to Adams left, and they invited the chairman of our department to become dean of agriculture, Gus Watkins.
You probably remember Gus.
Oh yes, yes.
The chief academic officer at that time was called the dean of the college?
Yeah, in those days all of the regular deans of the schools, and there were just a few colleges originally.
Reported to the dean of the college, who was the chief academic officer under the president.
And that was whom?
Well, it eventually became John Paul Abbott in about 1950, but originally it was not.
In between John Paul was Dr. Morgan, who became president.
Let's talk about Dr. Abbott for a moment.
Okay.
Characterize him.
Oh, I would call him a true southern gentleman in the best sense of the word.
He was very considerate of people, kindly in his approach to people.
A real Jew, in my opinion.
He may not have been the best or the greatest of the scholars, but he was a true professor.
And the president when you arrived?
The president was Dr. Bolton, and Gib Gilchrist was the chancellor.
They had just formed the system at that time.
Gilchrist had been president, but he moved to the chancellorship, and Bolton became the president.
Was he a vigorous leader, Bolton?
No, in fact there's hardly anything that registers on my mind that I would call it really happened outstanding.
I can't remember hearing anyone else mention it.
He was more or less, I shouldn't say this but I will, he was more or less fulfilling a position as far as I was concerned.
But in those days I was so busy with being a professor teaching and doing research that I cared less about the higher echelon.
What about Gilchrist?
Gilchrist was an able administrator.
He was tough as nails and hard to get along with.
And you better hew to his line or you were on the same wavelength.
Did you faculty members see the president or the chancellor much?
Very seldom.
I didn't meet Dr. Gilchrist or Dr. Bolton to one of the social affairs.
I never met him when I was interviewed or anything.
Do you remember what your first workloads were, teaching and research?
Well, it sounds rather fantastic in terms of modern schedules.
I had four sections, laboratory sections of beginning plant physiology, which I handled myself with one graduate student who only helped me in one of them.
And I taught two and three courses besides managing the laboratories.
It was about twenty-two, twenty-four hours, contact hours.
And it was made clear you were expected to do research in addition.
Oh, yeah.
I can never forget when I, I did meet Dean Shepardson when I first came and subsequently.
In fact, I will never forget when he called me in to review, they did a faculty assessment student rating of professors, which was the first time they'd done it at A&M.
He called me in to review the results, although I'd got a copy of them myself.
I thought they were quite good.
I kind of was cocky in those days, maybe still.
I walked over to get his accolades.
I didn't get accolades at all.
He said, Hall, you have one bad point here.
If you don't improve it, you won't be around next year.
One bad, he didn't say anything about the good points.
No.
Later, after he went to Washington, the Federal Reserve Board,
He wrote me a letter back saying, Dr. Hall, I always knew you were a good teacher, regardless of what I told you in my office.
Now, in those early years, were there merit salary increases?
No, not regular salary increases.
In fact, the maximum that anybody got, which usually, unless they were
threatening to leave or had a counter offer to meet.
It was about $200 a year.
I got regular, every time there was a salary increase, I got a salary increase.
And the major increase is when I made associate professorship.
I got $400 increase.
Hey, 400 a year.
Yeah.
And I think when I made full professor, I got something like $1,000 increase.
All right, now you arrived as an assistant professor.
As an assistant professor.
And you became a full professor how many years later?
So in five years you went.
Yeah.
It was the year before I, well I don't have the watch on, but you got one of them.
The first of those were given in 1955, and I made full professor the year before.
And you got one of them that year or the next year?
No, I got one of the first of the first five ever given.
That's what I thought.
Yeah, mine was

combination for teaching and research which they abolished the second year and became made it split it out into either research or teaching then they were four given wait excuse me three given in teaching one in teaching and research and one in student relations now when you received yours was it done as it was with mine a total surprise
Oh yeah, I didn't even know I'd been nominated.
Same here.
Gus Watkins later told me that he was instrumental in making the nomination.
He got a number of other people to support it.
No, I didn't know it.
In fact, we were over to, oh, it's abolished now where they used to hold the faculty meetings.
In Guyon Hall.
Guyon Hall, right.
And I went over there and I was just sort of relaxed and listening to the chatter, you know.
trying to get the thing over with so I could go home after it was late in the afternoon.
And all of a sudden they called my name and I staggered up there.
I actually thought I was never going to make it up there.
My knees were so weak I could hardly walk up to the podium.
I think for all of us, that was an unforgettable day.
How would you characterize the College of Agriculture at that point in terms of its emphasis, its momentum?
Well, I have to give Dean Shepardson and others, his predecessors, a lot of credit for building up a real fine school of agriculture.
In fact, in those days when I came here, the reputation of A&M was in agriculture.
It wasn't in engineering, despite what some of the engineers might want you to think.
Engineering did develop strongly when I was there, but agriculture and engineering was what A&M stood for, and it still was in those early days that I was here.
And by and large, the faculty had
done their doctoral degrees all across the nation, hadn't they?
Oh, yeah.
They were excellent teachers.
I would hire any number of those early people.
Many of them had offers to go to more prestigious places, and they stayed because they liked it here.
Where was the department housed?
Our department was housed in several buildings.
We didn't have a central location, but the main office, the headship or the chairman's, was in the old Ag Experiment Station, the red building, which subsequently was destroyed.
I was housed.
My office was in Old Science Hall, which also has been long gone.
And a number of others were strung around.
That's where they could find an office for them.
And your classes also were scattered.
Oh, yeah.
We didn't have a classroom where we could call our own, except one small one.
We had the laboratories, but you couldn't hold the lecture section.
In fact, there were large lecture sections.
I taught 200 to 300 students in some of the lectures.
Where were those classes held?
They were held either in the large
lecture halls like chemistry or ag engineering had a big tieredI don't know if you remember.
I can rememberwell, I won't say what I was going to say.
And your research, how didwhat was your beginning research topic?
Well, when I was at the University of Iowa before I left and at Kentucky, I started to work on the role of ethylene in plants and in organisms in general.
And I got interrupted because I was made acting head here in Kentucky.
I came here and
The first year I was doing research just on my own, no sponsorship.
I continued some of the ethylene research that I had started in Kentucky.
But the second year, Dr. Lewis gave me a 25 percent appointment in the Ag Experiment Station.
Of course, that had to have some practical foundation.
So I decided, being that ethylene was involved in an incision, to do a project on cotton defoliation.
and actually developed, made it possible for mechanical harvesting of cotton, not only in Texas, but elsewhere.
And I say in my book without any false modesty, I think we established the real
And you had not done cotton research before?
I hadn't seen a cotton plant before I came to Texas, no.
And about how long did it take from beginning of that research to have results that made you proud?
Oh, I was publishing or starting to write up papers from what I'd done in my graduate work at Kentucky all along when I was teaching, even at night.
And as soon as I started active research,
I was turning out two and three papers a year at least.
And the cotton project, how?
Oh, immediately.
You had to write your results up in what they called progress reports, which were published and distributed to the farmers, ranchers.
And then how soon did, how long did it take from the beginning of your research to the cotton farmer to start defoliating?
Oh, I would say eight to ten years, something like that.
Was there any private concern, private entrepreneur who became involved in the, in supporting the research?
Oh, yeah.
That was left mostly from research grants and contracts.
That's mostly what my graduate students and I did the research with.
I had the equivalent of about now would be several million dollars of sponsored research after about two or three years after I started there.
I got it from the National Science Foundation, from National Institutes of Health, from the
Cotton industry, National Cotton Council, headquartered in Memphis, gave me a large grant.
They were all interested in pushing it, yeah.
And it's really, that's what made the graduate students, their support came from all these grants.
All right, and then how, when did you become, begin to become a, here, an administrator?
Well, that was in 19...
I became, though, a department chairman before that.
When did you chair the department?
It was in 1956, I believe.
It's the year that Gus became dean of agriculture.
He insisted on twisting my arm to become chairman, which I regretted for a while because I wanted to do teaching and research entirely.
But in 1957, it was announced late there that
even though Dr. Tom Harrington had been both chancellor and president, that there was a need to bring in somebody to be president.
That was after Dave Morgan had left in sort of a huff with the board.
In fact, to put it bluntly, they fired him, although it wasn't announced that way.
Let's chat about him a minute.
Now I've heard 99th Hand that he had some ideas that were kind of similar to
to those that would become realities in the 60s.
That is entirely correct.
My book was a man with a lot of vision and a capable administrator.
But he got out of sync with the people that managed A&M
He wanted to push things too fast.
A&M was not responsive in those days for change.
Right.
Now, was Dr. Harrington already?

Dr. Harrington, when I first came here, Dr. Harrington was assistant dean of arts and sciences, and he was managing the O'Brien Air Force Base activity where a lot of the former military people were coming in to go to school.
And then he became dean of arts and sciences.
From there he became dean of the college.
He became president and then chancellor.
Was he chancellor over Morgan?
No, he became chancellor after Gilchrist.
So it was Gilchrist and Morgan that didn't jive as well as they might have.
Yeah.
No, to my knowledge, Tom Harrington and Morgan got along all right, but it was members of the board of directors we called in those days.
They didn't call them regents or any of it.
Was there any director that you know of who was more potent than the others in dealing with Morgan?
Yeah, I knew most of them at the time.
Pete Peterson from Fort Worth was on the board at that time.
The engineer, trying to think of his name, there's a building named after him on the campus.
He was from Beaumont.
He had a brother that also served on the board at one time, a German name.
Not Hal Booty?
No, Hal Booty.
Because he's Lebanese, he's later.
No, it was Evans was on the board during those years.
Well, it became not initially when I was here, but later.
And the man from San Antonio, I'm trying to think.
We'll think of those later.
All right.
So Morgan is gone.
And then Mr.
Rudder.
is brought over a little later, in 58 or 9?
He was brought over in 58, although the negotiations apparently happened in late 57.
Do you have any idea of
who the people were and what the process was that identified him.
Yeah.
Tony Heldenfels was the man I was trying to think of from Beaumont, was one of them.
Sterling Evans, Pete Peterson,
Oh, the Boydell, Dr. Boydell.
And there were several other men from Amarillo.
Oh, don't get old.
My memory's getting bad.
I can't remember him.
Begins with a W, I think.
Yeah, if I had my book here.
No, that's all right.
It's in that book.
We'll get that later in the second draft.
They were the main ones, I think.
Do you have any idea how they came to identify Rudder?
Well, the same way that I think most of the people in Texas knew him.
He was a famous war hero, and the governor enticed him to leave his ranch
to clean up the land scandal, rocked land office, which he did magnificently.
And people said, there's a natural leader.
And of course, military-minded people were very much part of A&M at that time.
And they were looking for a leader.
They weren't looking for an academician.
And do you recall your first impression of Mr. Rutter?
Yeah, I was always impressed with Mr. Rutter.
He was a dynamic individual.
If you didn't sit in his presence, you weren't impressed with him, or at least I was impressed with him.
He admitted to me right from the start that he didn't know much about academics.
He says, that's why I'm hiring you, Hall.
He hired me first as graduate dean.
But I really was dean of the college is what I was doing.
All right.
Now, when did that occur?
That was in 1958.
So soon after he got here.
Oh, yeah.
He interviewed me.
The first thing he did was hire Dorsey McCrory.
as his administrative assistant.

And he sent Dorothy out all around the campus to find candidates for appoint, because Boyd Page had left and announced just after Rutter was appointed that he was going to Iowa State as vice president, which he did.
And he told us in the inner circle he was leaving several months before it was made public.
But immediately, Rutter started to look for a replacement.
And he sent Dorsey all around the campus and different places to get information and so forth.
And he called me in.
I had met him previously, and I was still chairman of the department at the time.
And we were building a new building, the Plant Sciences Building, and I was having a ball doing it all.
And he called me in, and I thought he wanted to ask me how the Plant Science Building was coming.
All of a sudden he lowered the boom on me and said, Hall, I like your research and teaching record.
Would you like to be graduate dean?
And he bowed, floored me.
That was the last thing I had in mind.
Was that Mr. Rutter or was that McCrory?
That was Mr. Rutter.
Mr. Rutter.
Mr. Rutter didn't delegate things except the nasty things to people that he didn't want to do.
Now where did he office then?
In the Koch building?
He was in the Richard Koch building.
And
It became the president.
He didn't have the president's suite to start with, but he had it a few days.
All right, so you became graduate dean when?
As I recall, it was 1958, late in 58.
No, my appointment was announced July 58.
And the dean of the college then was whom?
And we didn't have a dean of the college.
Boyd Page had been both graduate dean and dean of the college, and he had left before I even assumed his office.
